summary: This document contains notes from a January 17, 2020 call regarding the DOJ Inspector General's investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's death. The discussion covers the IG's access to grand jury materials, the investigation into whether policy violations occurred by not providing Epstein with a cellmate, timing concerns about releasing the IG's report after the trial, and the handling of witness names in the report.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the investigation; the discussion concerns the circumstances of his death while in custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC).

events.title: Call regarding DOJ-IG Epstein investigation
events.description: A call was held to discuss the DOJ Inspector General's investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's death, focusing on access to materials, potential policy violations, and report timing.

keyFacts: The DOJ Inspector General is investigating whether there was a policy violation or administrative failure in not providing Jeffrey Epstein with a cellmate at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC).
The IG's investigation is being conducted under the 'IG Empowerment Act of 2016,' which grants the DOJ-IG access to all grand jury materials.
There is a desire from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York that any report from the IG be released after the trial (presumably Ghislaine Maxwell's).
The investigation involves reviewing witness statements, but the notes indicate that handwritten notes from at least one witness are not yet available.

The document discusses two divisions within the IG's office handling the report with different approaches to naming individuals: the Oversight Review Division uses all names in long reports, while the Investigations Division uses titles instead of names.
